name: cutandrun-tf-profiling
title: CUT&RUN Transcription Factor Binding
description: Map transcription factor binding sites with high precision using CUT&RUN. Requires fewer cells than ChIP-seq with superior signal-to-noise for TF binding analysis. Samplesheet format: `sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,replicate,antibody,control`
content:
CUT&RUN for Transcription Factors

CUT&RUN revolutionizes transcription factor mapping by eliminating ChIP-seq's limitations: no crosslinking artifacts, requires 100x fewer cells, and delivers exceptionally low background for clean TF binding profiles.

Why CUT&RUN for TFs?

ChIP-seq Challenges:

  • Requires 1-10 million cells
  • Crosslinking can create artifacts
  • High background from non-specific antibody binding
  • Expensive antibody consumption
  • Some TFs don't crosslink well

CUT&RUN Solutions:

  • Works with 10-100K cells (100x less!)
  • No crosslinking = no artifacts, native binding
  • In situ digestion = only target DNA released
  • Less antibody needed
  • Captures dynamic/transient TF binding

CUT&RUN vs ChIP-seq for TFs

FeatureCUT&RUNChIP-seq
Cell Input10-100K1-10M
BackgroundUltra-lowHigh
Peak SharpnessVery sharpBroader
Transient Binding✅ Captured❌ Often missed
Antibody1-5 μg10-20 μg
Protocol Time1 day3-4 days
Rare Cell Types✅ Feasible❌ Difficult

Transcription Factor Applications

Nuclear Receptors:

  • ERα: Estrogen receptor in breast cancer
  • AR: Androgen receptor in prostate cancer
  • GR: Glucocorticoid receptor in immune response
  • PPARγ: Metabolic regulation

Master Regulators:

  • OCT4, SOX2, NANOG: Pluripotency (stem cells)
  • MYOD: Muscle differentiation
  • PAX6: Eye development
  • GATA family: Hematopoiesis

Signal-Responsive TFs:

  • NF-κB: Inflammatory response (transient binding!)
  • STAT family: Cytokine signaling
  • AP-1 (FOS/JUN): Stress response
  • NFAT: T cell activation

Chromatin Organizers:

  • CTCF: Insulator, TAD boundaries (excellent with CUT&RUN)
  • Cohesin: Chromatin loops

Capturing Transient TF Binding

Problem with ChIP-seq:

  • Crosslinking "freezes" binding at moment of fixation
  • Dynamic TFs (NF-κB, STATs) may not be well-captured
  • Some TFs have low crosslinking efficiency

CUT&RUN Advantage:

  • No crosslinking = captures TFs in native state
  • MNase cuts immediately around bound TF
  • Can detect rapid binding/unbinding events
  • Better for stimulus-induced TFs

Pipeline Analysis

  1. Quality Control: FastQC, fragment size (<120bp for TFs)
  2. Alignment: Bowtie2 maps paired-end reads
  3. Spike-in Normalization: Quantitative comparison
  4. Peak Calling: SEACR (narrow peaks for TFs)
  5. Motif Analysis: HOMER finds TF motifs in peaks
  6. Footprinting: Fine-map exact binding sites within peaks
  7. Target Gene Assignment: Link TF binding to nearby genes
  8. Pathway Enrichment: What pathways are TF-regulated?

Fragment Size Interpretation

CUT&RUN fragment sizes reveal binding mode:

  • <120bp: TF bound to DNA (nucleosome-free)
  • ~180bp: TF + partial nucleosome wrapping
  • >200bp: Background/non-specific cutting

For TFs: Most signal should be <120bp (sharp, nucleosome-free binding)

Scientific Questions

  • TF Binding Sites: Where does this TF bind genome-wide?
  • Co-factor Recruitment: Does TF-A recruit TF-B?
  • Dynamic Binding: How does binding change with stimulus?
  • Rare Cell Types: TF binding in purified populations (e.g., FACS-sorted)
  • Drug Response: Do drugs alter TF binding?
  • Disease Variants: SNPs disrupting TF sites

Low Cell Input Use Cases

Rare Cell Populations:

  • FACS-sorted immune subsets (Tregs, Th17, etc.)
  • Neural stem cells from single brain region
  • Primary tumor infiltrating lymphocytes
  • Specific developmental stage embryos

Patient Samples:

  • Limited biopsy material
  • Rare disease samples
  • Precious primary cells

Applications

  • Cancer: Oncogenic TF binding (MYC, p53 mutants, ERα in breast cancer)
  • Immunology: T cell activation (NFAT, NF-κB), cytokine response
  • Stem Cells: Pluripotency network (OCT4/SOX2/NANOG), reprogramming
  • Development: Master regulators during differentiation
  • Drug Discovery: Nuclear receptor agonists/antagonists
  • Disease Modeling: Aberrant TF binding in disease

Recommended Workflow

Step 1: Optimize CUT&RUN

  • Start with 100K cells per sample
  • Titrate antibody (typically 1-5 μg)
  • Include IgG negative control
  • Add spike-in chromatin (Drosophila)

Step 2: Run Pipeline

  • Paired-end sequencing (25M reads)
  • Call peaks with SEACR (optimized for CUT&RUN)
  • Spike-in normalize for quantitative comparison

Step 3: Validate

  • Check fragment size (<120bp for TFs)
  • Confirm expected motif enrichment
  • Compare to ChIP-seq if available

Input Requirements

CSV samplesheet with columns:

  • group: Sample group name
  • replicate: Replicate number
  • fastq_1: Path to R1 FASTQ
  • fastq_2: Path to R2 FASTQ
  • control: IgG control sample name

Key Outputs

  • TF Peak Calls: SEACR narrow peaks (BED)
  • Spike-in Normalized Tracks: Quantitative BigWigs
  • Fragment Size Distribution: QC (<120bp for good TF signal)
  • Motif Enrichment: Expected TF motifs in peaks
  • Target Genes: TF-regulated gene lists
  • Differential Binding: Condition-specific TF binding
  • QC Report: MultiQC summary

Perfect for: TF binding • Low cell input • Rare cell types • Dynamic binding • No crosslinking • High resolution
